description: Scott Beck's blog post is the inspiration for this month's column and the Teacher Librarian poster. Beck is the director of Student Services for Secondary School for Norman Public Schools in Norman, Oklahoma. In Most Likely to Succeed, Dintersmith and Wagner provide a list of skills that "students--and educators--will continue to need as they progress...
text:
Scott Beck's blog post (2020) is the inspiration for this month's column and
the Teacher Librarian poster (see pages 32-33). Beck is the director of
Student Services for Secondary School for Norman Public Schools in Norman,
Oklahoma. In Most Likely to Succeed, Dintersmith and Wagner (as cited in Beck,
2020) provide a list of skills that "students--and educators--will continue to
need as they progress forward in their personal, civic, and professional
lives." These include:

* Critical thinking and problem-solving

* Collaboration across networks

* Agility and adaptability

* Initiative and entrepreneurship

* Effective oral, written, and multimedia communication

* Accessing and analyzing information

* Curiosity and imagination

All of the above are skills taught, supported, and promoted by school
librarians and accomplished in an information-rich setting--the library--with
the unique abilities of a certified librarian. The school librarian provides
equitable access to information in all formats within the context of teaching
information literacy skills. This, in turn, prepares students to be capable
learners, users of information, and communicators for life.

Beck's insight provides inspiration for the creation of the top 11+ reasons
schools need school librarians. The list was created to reflect how librarians
fulfill each role in a distinctive way, differentiating them from other
educators and capturing their unique expertise. School librarians are needed
because they:

1\. Advocate for inquiry, critical thinking, and problem-solving

2\. Curate print, virtual, and multimedia resources

3\. Link resources to literary and learning needs

4\. Model collaboration with teachers & students

5\. Teach information literacy to access, analyze, and apply

6\. Embrace curiosity and welcome change

7\. Create safe, welcoming spaces

8\. Herald the tenets of information citizenship

9\. Specialize in student choice & voice

10\. Put the "make" in makerspace.

11\. Enable online learnng and access 24/7. (see pages 32-33)

Beck (2020) challenges all educators to,

    
    
    Take a moment to sit down with your
       teacher librarian to dream together
       and to chart a course. Unlock the
       power of your library to drive a culture
       of deep learning in your school,
       and always remember, school is not
       preparation for real life, school is real
       life. At least, it should be--and your
       school librarians can help with that.

This is a call to school librarians to embody what Beck describes as the
nonnegotiable role of school librarians, which are reflected in the Teacher
Librarian poster. Remember: One of the strongest elements of school library
advocacy is when "others will act for and with you" (AASL, 2007), so recruit
your advocacy stakeholders to use and share the poster as they support you and
the school library.

REFERENCES

American Association of School Librarians (AASL). (2007). What is advocacy?
Retrieved from <http://www.ala.org/aasl/advocacy/definitions>

Beck, S. (2020, February 6). The nonnegotiable role of school librarians.
Retrieved from <http://blog.nassp.org/2020/02/06/the-nonnegotiable-role-of-
school-librarians/>

ADDITIONAL RESOURCES

American Library Association, et. al. (2013). The 100 things kids will miss if
they don't have a school librarian in their school, [poster] Retrieved from
<http://www.ala.org/aasl/sites/ala.org.aasl/files/content/aaslissues/advocacy/100_Things_Poster.pdf>

"The school librarian provides equitable access to information in all formats
within the context of teaching information literacy skills."

Deborah Levitov, Ph.D., is the editor of Teacher Librarian. Previously she
served as coordinator of Library Media Services for Lincoln Public Schools,
Lincoln, NE, and was a school librarian at the elementary level. Much of her
career, doctoral research, and writing have focused on advocacy for school
librarians and libraries.
[dlevitov@teacherlibrarian.com](mailto:dlevitov@teacherlibrarian.com).

Christie Kaaland, EdD, is associate editor of Teacher Librarian and director
of school library certification at Antioch University Seattle. Previous to
Antioch she worked as a teacher librarian in the Tacoma School District. Her
professional interests have led to promoting deeper collaboration between
school library programs and state legislative advocacy impacting school
libraries.
[ckaaland@teacherlibrarian.com](mailto:ckaaland@teacherlibrarian.com).

title: Top 11 + Reasons Schools Need School Librarians: (Now More Than Ever in the Time of Covid-19).(TIPS & TACTICS)
html:
Scott Beck's blog post (2020) is the inspiration for this month's column and the Teacher Librarian poster (see pages 32-33). Beck is the director of Student Services for Secondary School for Norman Public Schools in Norman, Oklahoma. In Most Likely to Succeed, Dintersmith and Wagner (as cited in Beck, 2020) provide a list of skills that "students--and educators--will continue to need as they progress forward in their personal, civic, and professional lives." These include:

* Critical thinking and problem-solving

* Collaboration across networks

* Agility and adaptability

* Initiative and entrepreneurship

* Effective oral, written, and multimedia communication

* Accessing and analyzing information

* Curiosity and imagination

All of the above are skills taught, supported, and promoted by school librarians and accomplished in an information-rich setting--the library--with the unique abilities of a certified librarian. The school librarian provides equitable access to information in all formats within the context of teaching information literacy skills. This, in turn, prepares students to be capable learners, users of information, and communicators for life.

Beck's insight provides inspiration for the creation of the top 11+ reasons schools need school librarians. The list was created to reflect how librarians fulfill each role in a distinctive way, differentiating them from other educators and capturing their unique expertise. School librarians are needed because they:

1. Advocate for inquiry, critical thinking, and problem-solving

2. Curate print, virtual, and multimedia resources

3. Link resources to literary and learning needs

4. Model collaboration with teachers & students

5. Teach information literacy to access, analyze, and apply

6. Embrace curiosity and welcome change

7. Create safe, welcoming spaces

8. Herald the tenets of information citizenship

9. Specialize in student choice & voice

10. Put the "make" in makerspace.

11. Enable online learnng and access 24/7. (see pages 32-33)

Beck (2020) challenges all educators to,

Take a moment to sit down with your
   teacher librarian to dream together
   and to chart a course. Unlock the
   power of your library to drive a culture
   of deep learning in your school,
   and always remember, school is not
   preparation for real life, school is real
   life. At least, it should be--and your
   school librarians can help with that.

This is a call to school librarians to embody what Beck describes as the nonnegotiable role of school librarians, which are reflected in the Teacher Librarian poster. Remember: One of the strongest elements of school library advocacy is when "others will act for and with you" (AASL, 2007), so recruit your advocacy stakeholders to use and share the poster as they support you and the school library.

REFERENCES

American Association of School Librarians (AASL). (2007). What is advocacy? Retrieved from http://www.ala.org/aasl/advocacy/definitions

Beck, S. (2020, February 6). The nonnegotiable role of school librarians. Retrieved from http://blog.nassp.org/2020/02/06/the-nonnegotiable-role-of-school-librarians/

ADDITIONAL RESOURCES

American Library Association, et. al. (2013). The 100 things kids will miss if they don't have a school librarian in their school, [poster] Retrieved from http://www.ala.org/aasl/sites/ala.org.aasl/files/content/aaslissues/advocacy/100_Things_Poster.pdf

"The school librarian provides equitable access to information in all formats within the context of teaching information literacy skills."

Deborah Levitov, Ph.D., is the editor of Teacher Librarian. Previously she served as coordinator of Library Media Services for Lincoln Public Schools, Lincoln, NE, and was a school librarian at the elementary level. Much of her career, doctoral research, and writing have focused on advocacy for school librarians and libraries. dlevitov@teacherlibrarian.com.

Christie Kaaland, EdD, is associate editor of Teacher Librarian and director of school library certification at Antioch University Seattle. Previous to Antioch she worked as a teacher librarian in the Tacoma School District. Her professional interests have led to promoting deeper collaboration between school library programs and state legislative advocacy impacting school libraries. ckaaland@teacherlibrarian.com.
